IBDB|first=The Broadway|last=League|website=Ibdb.com|accessdate=4 August 2017}} |- |} ==Philanthropist== Dena Hammerstein worked as a volunteer in [[New York City]] hospitals for over 15 years, and in 2003 received the United Hospital Funds New Leadership Group’s Humanitarian Award.[http://www.onlymakebelieve.org/who/board-of-directors/ Board of ''Only Make Believe''] She is Founder of '''Only Make Believe,''' a non-profit organisation that creates and performs interactive theatre for children in hospitals and care facilities, inspired by her early work as an actress in the UK touring special-needs schools.[http://www.onlymakebelieve.org/what About ''Only Make Believe'']{{cite web|url=http://articles.orlandosentinel.com/2012-08-13/entertainment/sns-201208130800reedbusivarietynvr1118057733-20120813_1_ian-mckellen-james-hammerstein-hospital-unit|title=D.C. gets Only Make Believe: Charity expands in 13th year|website=Articles.orlandosentinel.com|accessdate=4 August 2017}} {{Quote| Her greatest pride is reserved for the charity, "Only Make Believe", which she founded with the idea of letting the theatre help institutionalised children as it had once helped her. At first, she had thought of taking sick children to the theatre, but it was such a problem getting them there that they were too exhausted to enjoy the shows. Instead, she has brought the theatre to the children. The actors arrive with a large dressing-up trunk to rehearse a play in hospital using a script by Dena and children as performers. |[https://www.telegraph.co.uk/culture/theatre/3619052/I-was-on-the-road-to-make-believe.html ''I was on the road to make-believe'' – Cassandra Jardine, The Telegraph, 16 June 2004]}} ==Personal life== In 1970, a choreographer friend invited her to holiday in New York where she met Jamie Hammerstein. Married theatre director [[James Hammerstein]]Can't find date of marriage who directed her in ''Butley'', and has one son Simon Hammerstein (born 1977). ==Notes== {{Reflist|group=Issue}} ==References== {{Reflist}} ==External links== *[http://imdb.com/name/nm0792451/ Geraldine Sherman at IMDB] *[http://www.bfi.org.uk/films-tv-people/4ce2b9f3cd7ab Geraldine Sherman at BFI] *[http://www.ibdb.com/broadway-cast-staff/geraldine-sherman-84890 Geraldine Sherman at IBDB] *[http://www.ibdb.com/broadway-cast-staff/dena-hammerstein-480112 Dena Hammerstein at IBDB] ===Pictures=== *[http://www.aveleyman.com/Gallery/ActorsS/21605-8034-0.jpg Extra in ''A Hard Day's Night'': Girl Outside Secondhand Shop, 1964] from [http://www.aveleyman.com/FilmCredit.aspx?FilmID=8034 ''A Hard Day's Night'' Cast and Extras] *[http://www.paimages.co.uk/image-details/2.24384901 Publicity photo for ''King of the River'', 1966] *[http://yooniqimages.com/images/detail/102358475/Creative/take-a-girl-like-you-geraldine-sherman-john-bird-ronald-lacey Publicity photo for ''Take a Girl Like You'', 1970] *[http://www.onlymakebelieve.org/wp-content/uploads/2013/07/Dena.jpg Dena in 2013] *[http://static.playbill.com/dims4/default/d2746eb/2147483647/resize/800x450/quality/90/?url=http%3A%2F%2Fstatic.playbill.com%2F84%2F31%2F4c8bf59a4d5e95e2659847660e8c%2Fmakebelieve11.jpg Dena] {{Commonscat|Geraldine Sherman}} {{Authority control}} {{DEFAULTSORT:Sherman, Geraldine}} [[Category:Living people]] [[Category:1940 births]] [[Category:Actresses from London]] [[Category:British film actresses]] [[Category:British television actresses]] [[Category:British stage actresses]] [[Category:Theatre managers and producers]] [[Category:British people of Czech-Jewish descent]] [[Category:Women theatre managers and producers]]

{{Infobox film | name = Grand Canyon | image = Grand canyon poster.jpg | caption = Theatrical release poster | director = [[Lawrence Kasdan]] | producer = Michael Grillo
Lawrence Kasdan
Charles Okun | writer = [[Lawrence Kasdan]]
Meg Kasdan | starring = {{plainlist| * [[Danny Glover]] * [[Kevin Kline]] * [[Steve Martin]] * [[Mary McDonnell]] * [[Mary-Louise Parker]] * [[Alfre Woodard]]}} | music = [[James Newton Howard]] | cinematography = [[Owen Roizman]] | editing = [[Carol Littleton]] | distributor = [[20th Century Fox]] | released = {{film date|1991|12|25}} | runtime = 137 minutes | country = United States | language = English | budget = | gross = $40,991,329 (worldwide)[http://boxofficemojo.com/movies/?id=grandcanyon.htm "Grand Canyon,"] Box Office Mojo. Accessed Dec. 23, 2011. }} '''''Grand Canyon''''' is a 1991 American [[drama film|drama]] film directed and produced by [[Lawrence Kasdan]], and written by Kasdan with his wife Meg. Featuring an [[ensemble cast]], the film is about random events affecting a diverse group of people, exploring the race- and class-imposed chasms which separate members of the same community. The film was produced and distributed by [[20th Century Fox]] and was released on Christmas Day, 1991. ''Grand Canyon'' was advertised as "''[[The Big Chill (film)|The Big Chill]]'' for the '90s", in reference to an earlier Kasdan film. ==Plot== After attending a [[Los Angeles Lakers|Lakers]] basketball game, an immigration lawyer named Mack ([[Kevin Kline]]) finds himself at the mercy of potential [[Robbery|muggers]] when his car breaks down in a bad part of [[Los Angeles]] late at night. The muggers are talked out of their plans by Simon ([[Danny Glover]]), a tow truck driver who arrives just in time. Mack sets out to befriend Simon, despite their having nothing in common. In the meantime, Mack's wife Claire ([[Mary McDonnell]]) and his best friend Davis ([[Steve Martin]]), a [[film producer|producer]] of violent [[action film]]s, are experiencing life-changing events. Claire encounters an abandoned baby while jogging and becomes determined to [[adoption|adopt]] her. Davis suddenly becomes interested in philosophy rather than [[box-office]] [[profit (accounting)|profit]]s after being shot in the leg by a man trying to [[theft|steal]] his watch, vowing to devote the remainder of his career to eliminating violence from the [[Film|cinema]]. The film chronicles how these characters—as well as various acquaintances, co-workers and relatives—are affected by their interactions in the light of life-changing events. In the end, they visit the [[Grand Canyon]] on a shared vacation trip, united in a place that is philosophically and actually "bigger" than all their little separate lives. ==Cast== {{div col|colwidth=30em}} *[[Kevin Kline]] as Mack *[[Danny Glover]] as Simon *[[Steve Martin]] as Davis *[[Mary McDonnell]] as Claire *[[Mary-Louise Parker]] as Dee *[[Alfre Woodard]] as Jane *[[Jeremy Sisto]] as Roberto *[[Tina Lifford]] as Deborah *[[Randle Mell]] as The Alley Baron {{div col end}} ==Production== Parts of the film were shot at [[Glen Canyon]] in [[Utah]] as well as [[Los Angeles]] and [[Canoga Park, California]] and the Grand Canyon in [[Arizona]].{{cite book|last1=D'Arc|first1=James V.|title=When Hollywood came to town: a history of moviemaking in Utah|date=2010|publisher=Gibbs Smith|location=Layton, Utah|isbn=9781423605874|edition=1st}} The footage of the [[Los Angeles Lakers]] game in the film was shot before anybody knew Lakers guard [[Magic Johnson|Earvin "Magic" Johnson]] was HIV+. Rita Kempley, in her film review in ''[[The Washington Post]]'', pointed to this scene as proof that "... the filmmaker and his team ha[d] truly caught society on the verge."{{cite web | last=Kempley | first=Rita | title=Grand Canyon | url=https://www.washingtonpost.com/wp-srv/style/longterm/movies/videos/grandcanyonrkempley_a0a28b.htm | work=The Washington Post | date=January 10, 1992 | accessdate=May 6, 2018}} The character Davis is based on action film producer [[Joel Silver]].{{cite web | last=Wells | first=Jeffrey | title=Enough Already: Joel Silver, Model Mogul | url=http://articles.latimes.com/1993-02-21/entertainment/ca-953_1_joel-silver | work=Los Angeles Times | date=February 21, 1993 | accessdate=May 6, 2018}} ==Soundtrack== ''Grand Canyon: Music From the Original Motion Picture Soundtrack'' was released in 1992 on [[Milan Records]]. {{Infobox album | name = Grand Canyon:
Music from the Motion Picture Soundtrack | type = [[Soundtrack]] | artist = [[James Newton Howard]] | cover = | alt = | released = 1992 | recorded = 1990-1991 | venue = | studio = | genre = [[Instrumental|Instrumental pop]], [[pop rock]], [[soft rock]], [[jazz music|jazz]], [[orchestra music|orchestra]] | length = 42:53 | label = [[Milan Records|Milan]], [[RCA Records|RCA]], [[BMG Records|BMG]] | producer = [[James Newton Howard]], Waddy Wachtel | prev_title = | prev_year = | next_title = | next_year = }} ===Track listing=== {{Track listing | collapsed | total_length = 42:53 | title1 = Main Titles | length1 = 3:36 | title2 = Claire Returns the Baby | length2 = 1:12 | title3 = My Sister Lives Around Here/Those Rocks | length3 = 1:59 | title4 = Bloodstain | length4 = 2:06 | title5 = The Baby | length5 = 2:48 | title6 = Don't Work Late | length6 = 0:52 | title7 = Mack's Flashback | length7 = 1:22 | title8 = Don't Want Out | length8 = 6:45 | title9 = Searching for a Heart | length9 = 4:17 | title10 = Mack and Claire's Dream | length10 = 5:28 | title11 = Dee in Brentwood | length11 = 0:48 | title12 = Otis Runs | length12 = 3:54 | title13 = You White? | length13 = 1:27 | title14 = Keep the Baby | length14 = 1:30 | title15 = Doesn't Matter | length15 = 0:45 | title16 = Grand Canyon Fanfare/End Titles | length16 = 4:11 }} ===Personnel=== * [[James Newton Howard]]: Piano, Keyboards, Synthesized Bass, Synthesizer Programming, Programming, Orchestration * [[Dean Parks]], [[Michael Landau]], [[Jude Cole]], [[Davey Johnstone]]: Guitars * [[Michael Boddicker]]: Programming, Synthesizer, Synthesizer Programming * [[Simon Franglen]]: Synclavier Programming * [[John "J.R." Robinson]]: Drums * [[Neil Stubenhaus]]: Bass Guitar * [[Chuck Domanico]]: Acoustic Bass * [[Michael Lang (musician)|Michael Lang]]: Piano * [[Jeff Porcaro]], [[Joe Porcaro]], Emil Richards, Donald Williams, Mike Fisher: Percussions * [[Kirk Whalum]], [[Larry Williams]]: Saxophones * [[Paul Salamunovich]]: Choir Director, Choir Master * [[Warren Zevon]]: Performer (track 9) * Grand Canton Fanfare Orchestra: Performer (track 16) * Chris Boardman, Brad Dechter: Orchestrations * [[Marty Paich]]: Conductor * Tommy Johnson, Jim Self: Tubas * Rick Baptist, Charlie Davis, Gary Grant, Mario Guarneri, [[Jerry Hey]], John Richard Lewis, Jon Lewis, Warren Luening, Malcolm McNabb: Trumpets * Gayle Levant: Harp * Charles Loper, Bill Reichenbach Jr., George Thatcher: Trombones * David Duke, Joe Meyer, Brian O'Connor, John A. Reynolds, James Thatcher, Richard Todd: French Horns ==Reception== ===Critical response=== ''Grand Canyon'' received generally positive reviews from critics; it has a 7/10 "fresh" rating at [[Rotten Tomatoes]] and a critical rating of 76% based on 34 reviews.[http://www.rottentomatoes.com/m/1037642-grand_canyon/ "Grand Canyon (1991),"] Rotten Tomatoes. Accessed Dec. 22, 2011. [[Janet Maslin]] of ''[[The New York Times]]'' wrote, {{quote|Set in Los Angeles, and gliding gracefully among a representative set of characters, the film means to move through different economic strata, age groups and racial backgrounds in its search for common experience. If the ambition to do this is ultimately more impressive than the hazy, unfocused outcome, Mr. Kasdan still deserves a lot of credit for what he has tried.Maslin, Janet. [https://movies.nytimes.com/movie/review?res=9D0CE3D6113DF936A15751C1A967958260 "Review/Film; The Accidents and Miracles in Everyday Life,"] ''New York Times'' (Dec. 25, 1991).}} In a similar vein, ''[[Washington Post]]'' critic Rita Kempley wrote, {{quote|''Grand Canyon'' considers the ever-widening chasms that divide us, the shifting demographic fault lines that have set society quaking like the needle on [[Richter's scale]]. ... This City of the Angels captured by Kasdan, its skies buzzing with helicopters, reminds us most of all of [[Vietnam War|Vietnam]]. But this is not war, it's suicide, America in the latent stages of self-inflicted apocalypse. Kasdan validates our fears, but he doesn't strip us of all hope, for the central image also promises something greater than ourselves. The view from the edge can be awesome.Kempley, Rita. [https://www.washingtonpost.com/wp-srv/style/longterm/movies/videos/grandcanyonrkempley_a0a28b.htm "‘Grand Canyon’,"] ''[[The Washington Post]]'' (Jan. 10, 1992).}} [[Owen Gleiberman]] of ''[[Entertainment Weekly]]'' chided the film for its "... solemn zeitgeist chic," and called it "... way too self-conscious," but ultimately decided that "''Grand Canyon'' is finally a very classy soap opera, one that holds a generous mirror up to its audience's anxieties. It's the sort of movie that says: Life is worth living. After a couple of hours spent with characters this enjoyable, the message — in all its forthright sentimentality — feels earned."Gleiberman, Owen. [http://www.ew.com/ew/article/0,,309132,00.html "Grand Canyon (1991),"] ''Entertainment Weekly''. (Jan 10, 1992). Film critic [[Roger Ebert]] gave the film four out of four stars, and wrote, "In a time when our cities are wounded, movies like ''Grand Canyon'' can help to heal."Ebert, Roger. [http://rogerebert.suntimes.com/apps/pbcs.dll/article?AID=/19920110/REVIEWS/201100302 "Grand Canyon,"] ''[[Chicago Sun-Times]]'' (Jan. 10, 1992). Ebert's television reviewing partner [[Gene Siskel]] also loved the film,{{citation needed|date=December 2011}} with Ebert placing it at the #4 and Siskel at #6 on their 1991 top ten lists.{{citation needed|date=December 2011}} ===Awards=== The film won the [[Golden Bear]] for Best Film at the [[42nd Berlin International Film Festival]].{{cite web |url=http://www.berlinale.de/en/archiv/jahresarchive/1992/03_preistr_ger_1992/03_Preistraeger_1992.html |title=Berlinale: 1992 Prize Winners |accessdate=2011-05-24 |work=berlinale.de}} The screenplay was nominated for the Oscar (as Best Original Screenplay), the Golden Globe and the Writers Guild of America. ===Box office=== ''Grand Canyon'' was considered a minor failure at the box office,{{citation needed|date=December 2011}} taking in $40.9 million,[https://movies.yahoo.com/movie/1800168415/info "Grand Canyon (1991),"] Yahoo! Movies. Accessed 2 November 2009. and did not reap notable profits until it was released on video.{{citation needed|date=December 2011}} ==Legacy== [[Phil Collins]]' 1993 song "[[Both Sides of the Story]]" references the scene from ''Grand Canyon'' where the young mugger tells Simon (played by Danny Glover) that he carries a gun to make sure people respect (and fear) him.Kot, Greg. [http://articles.chicagotribune.com/1993-11-07/entertainment/9311070098_1_phil-collins-regular-guy-marriage/2 "Pop: Phil Collins, Regular Guy: And Like Regular Guys, He's Worried About His Kids,"] ''[[Chicago Tribune]]'' (Nov. 7, 1993). ==See also== *[[List of films featuring the deaf and hard of hearing]] ==References== {{Reflist}} ==External links== {{wikiquote}} * {{IMDb title|id=0101969|title=Grand Canyon}} * {{Amg movie|20447|Grand Canyon}} {{Lawrence Kasdan}} {{Golden Bear 1980-1999}} {{DEFAULTSORT:Grand Canyon (1991 Film)}} [[Category:1991 films]] [[Category:1990s drama films]] [[Category:American films]] [[Category:American drama films]] [[Category:Films directed by Lawrence Kasdan]] [[Category:English-language films]] [[Category:20th Century Fox films]] [[Category:Golden Bear winners]] [[Category:Films set in Arizona]] [[Category:Films set in Los Angeles]] [[Category:Films shot in Los Angeles]] [[Category:Films about race and ethnicity]] [[Category:Films shot in Arizona]] [[Category:Films shot in California]] [[Category:Films shot in Utah]] [[Category:Films scored by James Newton Howard]]

[[Image:Little Rock Desegregation 1957.jpg|thumb|290px|right|Massery shouting at Eckford (center)]]
'''Hazel Bryan Massery''' (born {{circa|1934}}) was a student at [[Little Rock Central High School]] during the [[Civil Rights Movement]]. She was depicted in an iconic photograph that showed her shouting at [[Elizabeth Eckford]], one of the [[Little Rock Nine]], during the [[Arkansas National Guard and the integration of Central High School|school integration crisis]]. In her later life, she sought to make amends for her behaviour, briefly becoming friends with Eckford. == Little Rock High School incident == On September 4th, 1957, nine African-American students entered Little Rock Central High School as the school's first black students, including Elizabeth Eckford. On her way to the school, a group of white teenage girls followed Eckford, chanting "Two, four, six, eight! We don't want to integrate!"<ref name = Telegraph>{{cite web|last1=Margolick|first1=David|title=Elizabeth Eckford and Hazel Bryan: the story behind the photograph that shamed America|url=https://www.telegraph.co.uk/news/worldnews/northamerica/8813134/Elizabeth-Eckford-and-Hazel-Bryan-the-story-behind-the-photograph-that-shamed-America.html|website=[[The Daily Telegraph|The Telegraph]]|publisher=The Telegraph|accessdate=15 May 2015 | date=October 9, 2011}}</ref> One of these girls was Hazel Bryan. [[Benjamin Fine]] of ''[[The New York Times]]'' later described her as "screaming, just hysterical, just like one of these Elvis Presley hysterical deals, where these kids are fainting with hysteria." Bryan is also credited as shouting, "Go home, nigger! Go back to Africa!"<ref name = Telegraph/><ref name="npr">{{cite web | url=https://www.npr.org/2011/10/02/140953088/elizabeth-and-hazel-the-legacy-of-little-rock | title='Elizabeth And Hazel': The Legacy Of Little Rock | publisher=[[NPR]] | work=[[Weekend Edition Sunday]] | date=October 2, 2011 | accessdate=January 20, 2018 | author=NPR staff}}</ref>
After the photo became public, Hazel started to receive "critical" mail, all from the north. Author [[David Margolick]] wrote that while Hazel only found the criticism "surprising", "Hazel's parents, though, found her sudden notoriety sufficiently alarming to pull her out of the school."<ref name = Margolick>{{cite magazine|last1=Margolick|first1=David| authorlink = David Margolick|title=Through a Lens, Darkly|url=http://www.vanityfair.com/news/2007/09/littlerock200709|date=September 2007|publisher=[[Vanity Fair (magazine)|Vanity Fair]]|accessdate=15 May 2015}}</ref>
Bryan left her new school when she was 17, married Antoine Massery and began a family. After that, her attitude toward [[Martin Luther King]] and the concept of desegregation changed. "Hazel Bryan Massery was curious, and reflective... One day, she realized, her children would learn that the snarling girl in their history books was their mother. She realized she had an account to settle."<ref name = Lives/>
In 1963, having changed her mind on integration and feeling guilt for her treatment of Eckford, Bryan contacted Eckford to apologize. They went their separate ways after this first meeting, and Eckford did not name the girl in the picture when asked about it by reporters.<ref name=Margolick/>
During the time after Little Rock, Hazel had become increasingly political, branching out into peace activism and social work.<ref name = Telegraph/> David Margolick discovered, "She taught mothering skills to unmarried black women, and took underprivileged black teenagers on field trips. She frequented the black history section at the local [[Barnes & Noble]], buying books by [[Cornel West]] and [[Shelby Steele]] and the companion volume to ''[[Eyes on the Prize]]''."<ref name=Margolick/>
Bryan hoped her reputation could be gained back, but this did not happen until the 40th anniversary of Central’s desegregation in 1997. [[Will Counts]], the journalist who took the famous picture, arranged for Elizabeth and Hazel to meet again. The reunion provided an opportunity for acts of reconciliation, as noted in this editorial from the ''[[Arkansas Democrat-Gazette]]'' on the first day of 1998:{{quote|One of the fascinating stories to come out of the reunion was the apology that Hazel Bryan Massery made to Elizabeth Eckford for a terrible moment caught forever by the camera. That 40-year-old picture of hate assailing grace — which had gnawed at Ms. Massery for decades — can now be wiped clean, and replaced by a snapshot of two friends. The apology came from the real Hazel Bryan Massery, the decent woman who had been hidden all those years by a fleeting image. And the graceful acceptance of that apology was but another act of dignity in the life of Elizabeth Eckford.<ref name="gazette98">[https://web.archive.org/web/20070626142614/http://www.jenningsosbornefamily.com/news/itn0198.html Happy old year — Thank you for 1997], editorial, ''Arkansas Democrat-Gazette'', January 1, 1998</ref>}}
== Friendship with Elizabeth Eckford == Despite feeling awkward when they first met, Eckford and Bryan surprisingly became friends afterwards:{{quote|They went to flower shows together, bought fabrics together, took mineral baths and massages together, appeared in documentaries and before school groups together. Since Elizabeth had never learned to drive, Hazel joked that she had become Elizabeth's chauffeur. Whenever something cost money, Hazel treated; it was awkward for Elizabeth, who had a hard time explaining to people just how poor she was.<ref name=Margolick/>}}
Soon after, the friendship began to fray. In 1999, David Margolick travelled to Little Rock and arranged to meet Elizabeth and Hazel. According to Hazel Bryan, she said, "I think she still… at times we have a little… well, the honeymoon is over and now we're getting to take out the garbage."<ref name = Telegraph/> As Eckford began to believe Bryan "wanted me to be cured and be over it and for this not to go on... She wanted me to be less uncomfortable so that she wouldn't feel responsible anymore." <ref name = Lives>{{cite web|last1=Margolick|first1=David|title=The Many Lives of Hazel Bryan|url=http://www.slate.com/articles/news_and_politics/history_lesson/2011/10/elizabeth_and_hazel_what_happened_to_the_two_girls_in_the_most_f.2.html|website=Slate|accessdate=13 May 2015}}</ref> The other eight of the Little Rock Nine didn't want this friendship to last any longer. The friendship quietly dissolved in 1999, when Elizabeth Eckford wrote "True reconciliation can occur only when we honestly acknowledge our painful, but shared, past" on the brick of Central High. This message affected their friendship. The principal of Central High School stated "I just had hoped that I could show this picture and say, 'This happened, and that happened, and now…' and there is no 'now'." She added, "And that makes me sad. It makes me sad for them, it makes me sad for the future students at our school, and for the history books, because I'd like a happy ending. And we don't have that."<ref name = Lives/>

revision.text: {{Dynamic list}} {{refimprove|date=August 2015}} This is a '''list of [[zombie]] related novels''' that are [[Wikipedia:Notability|notable]] themselves or by notable authors. {{zombies}} __TOC__ ==Novels and anthologies== {{compact ToC|side=yes|top=yes|num=yes}} {|class="wikitable sortable" ! Name !! Author !! Year !! class="unsortable"|Description |- |- |''Autumn: Aftermath'' || [[David Moody|Moody, David]]||2012||The final book in the Autumn series |- |''Autumn: The City'' || [[David Moody|Moody, David]]||2003||The second novel in the Autumn series begins by introducing new characters whose actions run concurrent with the action in the original novel, before uniting the two groups. |- |''Autumn: Disintegration'' || [[David Moody|Moody, David]]||2011||A continuation of the Autumn series |- |''Autumn: The Human Condition'' || [[David Moody|Moody, David]]||2005||A continuation of the Autumn series |- |''Autumn: Purification'' || [[David Moody|Moody, David]]||2004||The third novel in the Autumn series revolves around a military bunker sealed off from the outside world. |- |''The Awakening''||[[Brett McBean|McBean, Brett]]||2012|| A coming-of-age novel concerning a teenager’s tumultuous summer as he deals with the joys and hardships of growing up, while learning about the value of freedom at the hands of a kind but cursed old man. Contains strong elements of traditional Haitian Vodou and zombies. |- |''[[Breathers: A Zombie's Lament]]'' || [[S. G. Browne|Browne, S. G.]]||2009||A dark, comedic take on zombies told from the point of view of a recently reanimated corpse. |- |''[[Cell (novel)|Cell]]''|| [[Stephen King|King, Stephen]]||2006||Anyone talking on a cell phone after a particular event becomes an aggressive, bloodthirsty zombie.{{cite web| last =| first =| authorlink =| coauthors =| title =Cell Review from Pickerington Public Library| work =| publisher =[[Publishers Weekly]]| date =2006-01-02| url =http://www.supportlibrary.com/nl/br.cfm?re=890&url=%40nl_bookview.cfm%3Fx%3D890%26bn%3D%252A%252E%252E%2520%2522P%2524O%2520Z%255D3%255DI0%2520%2520%250A| archive-url =https://web.archive.org/web/20081201071518/http://www.supportlibrary.com/nl/br.cfm?re=890&url=%40nl_bookview.cfm%3Fx%3D890%26bn%3D%252A%252E%252E%2520%2522P%2524O%2520Z%255D3%255DI0%2520%2520%250A| dead-url =yes| archive-date =2008-12-01| format =| doi =| accessdate =2008-08-28}} |- |''[[City of the Dead (novel)|City of the Dead]]''||[[Brian Keene|Keene, Brian]]||2005||This is the official followup to ''[[The Rising (Keene novel)|The Rising]]''. Demons possess the bodies of the dead, including animals. One man attempts to reach his son. |- |''[[The Dead (Higson novel)|The Dead]]''||[[Charlie Higson|Higson, Charlie]]||2010|| A young adult novel. Adults over sixteen turn to zombies and young survivors battle against them. |- |''Dead City''||[[Joe McKinney (author)|McKinney, Joe]]||2006|| Battered by five cataclysmic hurricanes in three weeks, the Texas Gulf Coast and half of the Lone Star state is reeling from the worst devastation in history. A deadly virus has broken out, returning the dead to life. |- |''[[Dead of Night (zombie novels)|Dead of Night]]''||[[Jonathan Maberry|Maberry, Jonathan]]||2011|| A prison doctor injects a condemned serial killer with a formula designed to keep his consciousness awake while his body rots in the grave. But all drugs have unforeseen side-effects. Before he could be buried, the killer wakes up. Hungry. Infected. Contagious. This is the way the world ends. Not with a bang...but a bite. |- |''[[Dead Sea (novel)|Dead Sea]]''||[[Brian Keene|Keene, Brian]]||2007|| A zombie apocalypse starts with undead rats emerging from Baltimore's sewers. |- |''[[Deadline (Grant novel)|Deadline]]''||[[Mira Grant|Grant, Mira]]||2011|| A continuation of ''[[Feed (Grant novel)|Feed]]''. |- |''[[Death Troopers]]''||[[Joe Schreiber|Schreiber, Joe]]||2009|| A story in the [[Star Wars universe]] about an Imperial prison ship stranded in space, encountering another ship crammed with the ship's crew, which have been turned into zombies due to a bio-weapon the ship was carrying. |- |''[[The Enemy (Higson novel)|The Enemy]]''||[[Charlie Higson|Higson, Charlie]]||2009|| A young adult novel. Surviving youngsters battle adults who have become zombies. |- |''[[The End (Higson novel)|The End]]''||[[Charlie Higson]]||2012|| A post-apocalyptic young adult horror novel and the seventh book in a planned seven-book series, titled ''The Enemy''. |- |''[[The Fallen (Higson novel)|The Fallen]]''||[[Charlie Higson]]||2013|| A post-apocalyptic young adult horror novel and the fifth book in a planned seven-book series, titled ''The Enemy''. |- |''[[The Fear (Higson novel)|The Fear]]''||[[Charlie Higson|Higson, Charlie]]||2011||A young adult novel. Surviving youths battle "mothers" and "fathers" who have fallen ill. |- |''[[Feed (Grant novel)|Feed]]''||[[Mira Grant|Grant, Mira]]||2010|| News reporters blogging in a world that survives a zombie apocalypse. |- |''[[The Forest of Hands and Teeth]]'' || [[Carrie Ryan|Ryan, Carrie]] ||2009||Teen book. In a village generations after the zombie apocalypse a 16-year-old struggles with her town's religious rules until the village walls are breached and she is forced to flee into the woods.{{cite news| url=http://www.post-gazette.com/pg/09146/972132-44.stm| work=[[Pittsburgh Post Gazette]]| title=Zombies Rise in Teen Lit |accessdate=2009-08-08 | date=2009-05-26}} |- |''[[Friday the 13th (franchise)|Friday the 13th]]: The Jason Strain'' || [[Christa Faust|Faust, Christa]] ||2006|| An attempt at replicating the immortality and healing factor of [[Jason Voorhees]] goes wrong, and results in a zombie plague. |- |''[[Charlie_Higson#The_Enemy_short_story|Geeks vs. Zombies]]''||[[Charlie Higson]]||2012|| A companion short story book in ''[[The Enemy (Higson novel)|The Enemy]]'' series portrays an exclusive scene from ''[[The Fear (Higson novel)|The Fear]]'' (2011), on World Book Day. |- |''[[Generation Dead]]'' || [[Daniel Waters (novelist)|Waters, Daniel]] ||2008||Teen book. In the present day, U.S. teens are randomly rising from the dead, and the country is in turmoil over the question of zombie civil rights. |- |''[[The Girl with All the Gifts]]'' || [[Mike Carey (writer)|M.R. Carey]] ||2014|| In a [[Dystopia|dystopian]] future, most of humanity is wiped out by a fungal infection. The infected quickly lose their mental powers and feed on the flesh of healthy humans. |- |''[[Handling the Undead]]''|| [[John Ajvide Lindqvist|Lindqvist, John Ajvide]]||2005||During a massive heatwave the unexplained resurrection of thousands of recently deceased people begins in [[Stockholm]], [[Sweden]]. David, whose wife has recently died, has gone to the morgue to identify remains of his lost love only to find that she has begun to move. It's terrifying to David, but gives him a strange kind of hope. |- |''[[Herbert West--Reanimator]]'' || [[H.P. Lovecraft|Lovecraft, H.P.]] || 1921 || Medical doctor invents a serum that re-animates corpses. |- |''History is Dead: A Zombie Anthology'' || [[Kim Paffenroth|Paffenroth, Kim (editor)]] || 2007 || Twenty short stories by twenty different authors with zombies in alternate histories. |- |''[[The Hunted (Higson novel)|The Hunted]]''||[[Charlie Higson]]||2014|| A post-apocalyptic young adult horror novel and the sixth book in a planned seven-book series, titled ''The Enemy''. |- |''Husk'' || [[Corey Redekop|Redekop, Corey]] || 2012 || A blackly humorous take on the genre, as an unwilling but terribly hungry zombie strives to continue his career as an actor. |- |''[[Illuminatus!]]''|| [[Robert Shea|Shea, Robert]] and [[Robert Anton Wilson|Wilson, Robert Anton]] ||1976||In the third volume, ''Leviathan'', opens with a rock festival on the shores of Lake Totenkopf in Bavaria. Unknown to all except the heroes and the villains, the bodies of an entire division of the [[Waffen-SS]] were interred on an underwater plateau supported by a "biomystical field" to maintain bodily integrity. At the climax of the festival, they will return to life as zombies, surface, and slaughter all 250,000 hippies at the festival. |- |''Kiss of Life'' || [[Daniel Waters (novelist)|Waters, Daniel]] ||2009||Teen book. Sequel to ''[[Generation Dead]]''. |- |''The Living Dead 2'' || [[John Joseph Adams|Adams, John Joseph]] || 2010 || A collection of 44 short stories about zombies includes contributions by [[Max Brooks]], [[Robert Kirkman]], and [[David Wellington (author)|David Wellington]]. |- |''[[Monster Island (Wellington novel)|Monster Island]]''|| [[David Wellington (author)|Wellington, David]] ||2006||In New York City, the dead walk the streets. From the other side of the planet, a small but heavily-armed group of schoolgirls-turned-soldiers comes in search of desperately needed medicine, with a former UN weapons inspector as their local guide. |- |''[[Monster Nation (novel)|Monster Nation]]''||[[David Wellington (author)|Wellington, David]] ||2006|| A prequel to ''Monster Island'' where a sentient zombie tries to cure herself. |- |''[[Monster Planet (novel)|Monster Planet]]''||[[David Wellington (author)|Wellington, David]] ||2007|| Sentient zombies are intent on taking over the world killing the living with a nuclear weapon. |- |''Les morts ont marché''|| [[:fr:Mathieu Fortin|Mathieu Fortin]] ||2011|| In Saint-Liconet, a zombie outbreak took place. To try finding who was the first living dead among the eight last suspects, you read interviews with witnesses, autopsy reports, and proofs analysis reports. |- |''[[Necromancer (novel)|Necromancer]]''||Harper, Scott ||2009||| Sequel to ''Predators or Prey?''. Monster hunter Wendy Markland fights zombies in the Pine Barrens of New Jersey. |- |''[[On the Far Side of the Cadillac Desert With Dead Folks]]'' || [[Joe R. Lansdale|Lansdale, Joe R.]] ||1989|| A bounty hunter chases his quarry in a land where the "dead folks" have re-animated due to a bacterium which has escaped a lab. |- |''[[On Stranger Tides]]'' || [[Tim Powers|Powers, Tim]] ||1988||Puppeteer John Chandagnac, who was sailing to Jamaica, has no choice but to join the buccaneers who have taken him prisoner. Blackbeard is assembling an empire of ruthless navy of pirates, living and undead, to voyage to the fabled Fountain of Youth. John, now known as Jack Shandy, tries to free himself from Blackbeard's deadly supernatural domination. |- |''[[Patient Zero: A Joe Ledger Novel]]''||[[Jonathan Maberry|Maberry, Jonathan]]||2009|| A radical Middle Eastern terrorist group plans to release a deadly bio-weapon on the American people. |- |''[[Pontypool Changes Everything]]'' || [[Tony Burgess (author)|Burgess, Tony]] ||1998||The dark side of humanity as an epidemic virus terrorizes the earth. |- |''[[Pride and Prejudice and Zombies]]''||[[Seth Grahame-Smith|Grahame-Smith, Seth]]||2009||[[Mashup (book)|Mashup]] combining [[Jane Austen|Jane Austen's]] classic 1813 novel ''[[Pride and Prejudice]]'' with elements of modern zombie fiction.{{cite news |title= Pride and Prejudice, Now With Zombies! |url=http://www.time.com/time/arts/article/0,8599,1889075,00.html |date=2009-04-02 |accessdate= 2009-04-04 | work=Time |first=Lev | last=Grossman}} |- |''[[Pride and Prejudice and Zombies: Dawn of the Dreadfuls]]'' || [[Steve Hockensmith|Hockensmith, Steve]] || 2010 || Prequel to ''Pride and Prejudice and Zombies''. |- |''[[Pride and Prejudice and Zombies: Dreadfully Ever After]]'' || [[Steve Hockensmith|Hockensmith, Steve]] || 2011 || Sequel to ''Pride and Prejudice and Zombies''. |- |''Le protocole Reston''|| [[:fr:Mathieu Fortin|Mathieu Fortin]] ||2009|| In the city of Trois-Rivières, a mutant Asian monster escapes from a boat and a zombie outbreak begins. The governments try to keep the story from the media while a high school teacher and his roommate try to survive to their zombie neighbour. |- |''Raising Stony Mayhall'' || [[Daryl Gregory|Gregory, Daryl]]||2011||Set in 1968, after the first zombie apocalypse, the body of a teenage mother is discovered in the snow, clutching a dead baby. The dead child begins to grow. |- |''[[Resident Evil (series)#Novels|Resident Evil: Caliban Cove]]'' ||[[S.D. Perry|Perry, S.D.]]||1998 || A paramilitary force investigates an Umbrella cover facility. |- |''[[Resident Evil (series)#Novels|Resident Evil: City of the Dead]]'' ||[[S.D. Perry|Perry, S.D.]] ||1999 || Adaptation of ''[[Resident Evil 2]]''. |- |''[[Resident Evil (series)#Novels|Resident Evil: Code Veronica]]'' ||[[S.D. Perry|Perry, S.D.]] ||2001 || Adaptation of ''[[Resident Evil Code: Veronica]]''. |- |''[[Resident Evil (series)#Novels|Resident Evil: Nemesis]]'' ||[[S.D. Perry|Perry, S.D.]]||1998 || Adaptation of ''[[Resident Evil (1996 video game)|Resident Evil]]''. |- |''[[Resident Evil (series)#Novels|Resident Evil: Underworld]]'' ||[[S.D. Perry|Perry, S.D.]]||1999|| A monster-creation lab is targeted for destruction. |- |''[[Resident Evil (series)#Novels|Resident Evil: Zero Hour]]''||[[S.D. Perry|Perry, S.D.]]||2004 || Adaption of ''[[Resident Evil 0]]''. |- |''[[The Rising (Keene novel)|The Rising]]''||[[Brian Keene|Keene, Brian]]||2004||Demons possess the bodies of the dead, including animals. One man attempts to reach his son. |- |''[[The Sacrifice (Higson novel)|The Sacrifice]]''||[[Charlie Higson]]||2012|| A post-apocalyptic young adult horror novel and the fourth book in a planned seven-book series, titled ''[[The Enemy (Higson novel)|The Enemy]]''. |- |''[[The Stupidest Angel: A Heartwarming Tale of Christmas Terror]]''|| [[Christopher Moore (author)|Moore, Christopher]]||2004||In his inept attempt to bring "Santa" back to life, an angel causes the townspeople of Pine Cove to fall under siege by brain-hungry zombies who arise from their burial plots. |- |''[[Undead]]''||[[John A. Russo|Russo, John A.]]||2010||A novelization of ''Night of the Living Dead'' and a sequel called ''Return of the Living Dead''. |- |''The Undead: Zombie Anthology''||D. L. Snell (Editor), Elijah Hall (Editor), [[Eric Shapiro]] (Contributor) ||2005|| Collection of 23 stories. Classic tales of survival in a world populated by the living dead as well as an array of unique takes on the zombie genre from authors including [[David Wellington (author)|David Wellington]] and [[David Moody]]{{cite book|title=The Undead: Zombie Anthology|authors=D.L. Snell (Editor), Elijah Hall (Editor), Eric Shapiro (Contributor)|year=2005| publisher=Permuted Press|ISBN= 978-0976555940 }} |- |''Under a Graveyard Sky''||[[John Ringo|Ringo, John]] ||2013|| The story of a family escaping a zombie epidemic in the US on a sailboat and the beginning of the process of finding survivors on the high seas as a prelude to retaking the mainland. Book one of the Black Tide Rising series. |- |''[[The Walking Dead: Rise of the Governor]]''||[[Robert Kirkman|Kirkman, Robert]] and [[Jay Bonansinga|Bonasinga, Jay]]||2011|| It depicts the journey of Philip Blake in the early days of the undead apocalypse to his eventual rise as "The Governor" of Woodbury. |- |''[[The Walking Dead: The Road to Woodbury]]''||[[Robert Kirkman|Kirkman, Robert]] and [[Jay Bonansinga|Bonasinga, Jay]]||2012|| It follows the travails of Lilly Caul who finds herself coming in contact with the "Governor" of Woodbury, a refuge amongst the zombie apocalypse that is not what it seems. The second of a planned trilogy. |- |''[[Warm Bodies]]''||[[Isaac Marion|Marion, Isaac]]||2010||R is a zombie who is a little different than his fellow Dead. He meets Julie Grigio, a Living girl, and ends up falling in love. |- |''[[World War Z]]'' || [[Max Brooks|Brooks, Max]]||2007||An oral history told by many survivors of the start, during, and aftermath of the zombie apocalypse.{{cite web |url=http://www.eatmybrains.com/showfeature.php?id=55 |title=Exclusive Interview: Max Brooks on World War Z |work=Eat My Brains! |date=October 20, 2006 |accessdate=April 26, 2008 }}{{cite web |url=http://www.untitledbooks.com/features/features/the-end-of-the-world-as-we-know-it/ |title=The End of the World as We Know it |accessdate=September 21, 2008 |last=Currie |first=Ron |date=September 5, 2008 |work=Untitled Books}} |- |''[[Darren Shan#Zom-B|Zom-B]]''||[[Darren Shan|Shan, Darren]]||2012||When news reports start appearing of a zombie outbreak in Ireland, B Smith's racist father thinks it is a joke—but even if it is not, he figures, it is ok to lose a few Irish. When zombies attack B's school, B is forced on a mad dash through the serpentine corridors, making allegiances with anyone with enough guts to fight off their pursuers. |- |''[[Zom-B: Angels]]''||[[Darren Shan|Shan, Darren]]||2013||The fourth book in the Zom-B series. B finds refuge with Angels, a group of teenagers who are dedicated to the task of restoring order back to the living. They are led by a mysterious, kindly doctor who can answer many of the questions that have been thrown up so far in the series. |- |''[[Zom-B: Baby]]''||[[Darren Shan|Shan, Darren]]||2013||The fifth book in the Zom-B series. B is trying to settle into life with the Angels, but finds it hard to believe some of Dr. Oystein's claims. When she decides to seek refuge elsewhere, she scours the streets of London in search of a place to call home. Wwhat she finds will lead B to question everything that she has ever held to be true. |- |''[[Zom-B: City]]''||[[Darren Shan|Shan, Darren]]||2013||The third book in the Zom-B series. B explores the streets of London, where we get our first glimpses of what has happened to the world in the wake of the zombie attacks. |- |''[[Zom-B: Gladiator]]''||[[Darren Shan|Shan, Darren]]||2014||The sixth book in the Zom-B series. B Smith has decided to live — and to fight for good as long as possible. However, London is overridden with the brain-eating undead and swarming with human mercenaries whose sense of right and wrong dissolved when society did. When they lay a trap, B is captured. And it will take dozens of battles—and the fight of a lifetime—to escape. |- |''[[Zom-B: Mission]]''||[[Darren Shan|Shan, Darren]]||2014||The seventh book in the Zom-B series. B Smith and the other Angels receive their first mission - to safely escort a group of human survivors from the zombie-infested streets of London to New Kirkham, a barricaded safe haven in the country. But after battling through crowds of undead monsters, B discovers that the survivors of the town do not necessarily represent the best of humanity... |- |''[[Zom-B: Underground]]''||[[Darren Shan|Shan, Darren]]||2013||The second book in the Zom-B series. Waking up in an underground military complex, months after the zombie outbreak, B has no memory of the last few months. As B learns more about the zombies held in the complex, and the scientists keeping them captive, unease settles in. |- |''[[Zombie Apocalypse!]]''||[[Stephen Jones (author)|Jones, Stephen]]||2010|| A [[mosaic novel]] in which interconnected narratives create a unique vision of the end of the world brought about by a plague. |- |''[[Zombie Apocalypse! Fightback]]''||[[Stephen Jones (author)|Jones, Stephen]]||2012|| The sequel to ''Zombie Apocalypse!'' The human fightback against the legions of the walking dead begins. |- |''[[The Zombie Survival Guide]]''||[[Max Brooks|Brooks, Max]]||2003||An earnest discussion of various survival techniques in a world threatened by zombies. |- |''[[Zombies: A Record of the Year of Infection]]''||[[Don Roff|Roff, Don]]||2009|| A man writes in his bird watching journal about trying to survive in a zombie apocalypse. |- |''[[Zone One]]''||[[Colson Whitehead|Whitehead, Colson]]||2011||Mark Spitz is a "sweeper," clearing away stragglers from Manhattan's Zone One district after the zombie attacks. These trapped souls are malfunctioning zombies, destined to ceaselessly repeat mundane acts they carried out while alive. |- |} ==Nonfiction== {|class="wikitable sortable" ! Name !! Author !! revision.comment: Robot - Speedily moving category Text societies to [[:Category:Text publication societies]] per [[WP:CFDS|CFDS]].
revision.text:
{{Italic title}} [[File:Monumenta Germaniae Historica.png|thumb|''Monumenta Germaniae Historica''.]] The '''''Monumenta Germaniae Historica''''' (frequently abbreviated '''MGH''' in bibliographies and lists of sources) is a comprehensive series of carefully edited and published [[primary source]]s, both [[chronicle]] and [[Archives|archival]], for the study of [[History of Germany|German history]] (broadly conceived) from the end of the [[Roman Empire]] to 1500.<ref name=Holland1910>{{Citation | title = [[Encyclopædia Britannica Eleventh Edition|Encyclopædia Britannica]] | publication-place = New York | publication-date = 1910 | edition=11th | oclc = 14782424 | chapter = Germany: Bibliography of German History |author= Arthur William Holland | chapterurl = https://books.google.com/books?id=l9I9AQAAMAAJ&pg=PA899 }}</ref> Despite the name, the series covers important sources for the history of many countries besides Germany, since the Society for the Publication of Sources on Germanic Affairs of the Middle Ages has included documents from many other areas subjected to the influence of Germanic tribes or rulers (Britain, Czech lands, Poland, Austria, France, Low Countries, Italy, Spain, etc.). The editor from 1826 until 1874 was [[Georg Heinrich Pertz]] (1795–1876); in 1875 he was succeeded by [[Georg Waitz]] (1813-1886) .
==History== The MGH was founded in Hanover as a private [[text publication society]] by the [[Prussia]]n reformer [[Heinrich Friedrich Karl vom und zum Stein|Heinrich Friedrich Karl Freiherr vom Stein]] in 1819. The first volume appeared in 1826. The editor from 1826 until 1874 was [[Georg Heinrich Pertz]], who was succeeded by [[Georg Waitz]]. Many eminent medievalists from Germany and, eventually, other countries, joined in the project of searching out and comparing manuscripts and producing scholarly editions. The motto chosen, ''Sanctus amor patriae dat animum'' ("Holy love for the fatherland gives the spirit") is explained as linking [[Romantic nationalism]] with professional scholarship. In 1875, the MGH was established as a more formal institution with headquarters in [[Berlin]].
In 1935, the organization was taken over by the state and renamed the ''Reichsinstitut für ältere deutsche Geschichtskunde'' (National Institute for Older German History). This was abolished in 1945, at the end of [[World War II]].
However, the institute was subsequently revived under its original name with the support of German institutions and the [[Austrian Academy of Sciences]].<ref>Knowles 1960.</ref> The Monumenta Germaniae Historica Institute has been located in Munich since 1949 and possesses a large specialized library on the medieval history of Germany and Europe, including Church history, along with 130,000 monographs and approximately 150,000 dependent writings.<!--Inhaltlich deckt die Bibliothek bzw. der frei zugängliche OPAC die mittelalterliche Geschichte Deutschlands und Europas mit Berücksichtigung der Kirchengeschichte ab. Der OPAC weist neben 130.000 Monographien auch ca. 150.000 unselbständige Schriften nach.--><ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.bib-bvb.de/bib_schule/infoblatt4-geschichte-theologie.pdf |title=BibliotheksVerbund Bayern |accessdate=2008-09-17 |deadurl=bot: unknown |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20110721100240/http://www.bib-bvb.de/bib_schule/infoblatt4-geschichte-theologie.pdf |archivedate=July 21, 2011 |df= }} {{de icon}}</ref> It moved into its current premises in the building of the [[Bavarian State Library]] in 1967.
The project, a major effort of historical scholarship, continues in the 21st century. In 2004 the MGH, with the support of the [[Deutsche Forschungsgemeinschaft]], made all of its publications in print for more than five years available online, in photo-digital reproduction, via a link on the MGH homepage.
==Divisions== The series falls into five main divisions, ''Antiquitates'', ''Diplomata'', ''Epistolae'', ''Leges'' and ''Scriptores'', with an additional smaller division of ''Necrologia''. Many subsidiary series have also been established, including a series of more compact volumes for school use (''Scriptores in usum scholarum'') and special studies (''MGH Schriften'').
==See also== * [[Historiography of Germany]] *[[Wilhelm Levison]]
==References== <references/>
==Bibliography== * {{Cite journal |doi=10.2307/3678777 |volume=10 |pages=129–150 |last=Knowles |first=M. D. |authorlink=David Knowles (scholar) |title=Presidential Address: Great Historical Enterprises III. The Monumenta Germaniae Historica |journal=Transactions of the Royal Historical Society |series=5th ser. |year=1960 |jstor=3678777 }} Reprinted in {{cite book |publisher=Nelson |last=Knowles |first=David |title=Great Historical Enterprises: problems in monastic history |location=London |year=1963 |pages=63–97 }}
==External links== *[http://www.mgh.de/fileadmin/Downloads/pdf/MGH-Gesamtverzeichnis_2015_web-2.pdf 2015 list of publications] {{de icon}} *[http://www.mgh.de/ The MGH homepage] {{de icon}} *[http://www.dmgh.de/ Digital MGH homepage] {{de icon}} *[https://archive.org/search.php?query=monumenta%20germaniae%20historica Monumenta Germaniae Historica on Archive.org] {{en icon}}
{{Authority control}}

revision.comment: Robot - Moving category Music organizations in Spain‎ to [[:Category:Music organizations based in Spain‎]] per [[WP:CFD|CFD]] at [[Wikipedia:Categories for discussion/Log/2018 October 9]].
revision.text:
{{multiple issues| {{Orphan|date=February 2016}} {{notability|org|date=March 2016}} {{Underlinked|date=March 2016}} }} '''Musethica''' is a non-governmental organization that introduces a new concept of education to classical music performance. The central objective of Musethica is to create a model for excellent music students to perform on a regular basis for different audiences as an integral part of their education.
A small, carefully selected group of young musicians participate in master classes conducted by world-renowned musicians, which often perform together with the young musicians.
The concerts comprise the finest repertoire of chamber music from solo performances to octet, and the young musicians receive no fee for their performances.
The concerts take place at a great variety of locations within the community: schools of special education, hospitals, psychiatric centers, prisons, centers for the homeless, community centers, social enterprises and other places.
The model provides the students with the opportunity to play a huge number of yearly concerts which tremendously improves their musical and instrumental abilities and brings joy and happiness to many children and adults during the academic school year.<ref>Jerusalem Post, (10.15.2015) “Musethica hath power for one and all” http://www.jpost.com/Magazine/Music-hath-power-for-one-and-all-426012</ref> it is a new element in music education,<ref>García, R. (2015): “Como preparar con éxito un concierto o audición”, Redbook Ediciones, Barcelona, pp. 175-177</ref> an element which was missing in the official curriculum of young performing musicians.
== History == The Musethica concept was conceived in 2009 by the violist [[Avri Levitan]] and was officially launched in 2012 in [[Zaragoza]], Spain under the auspices of Levitan and Professor Carmen Marcuello. As of 2017, Musethica has five active associations: in Spain, Germany, Israel, Poland and Sweden. Musethica is also active in France, China and Austria.

Opera World (18.12.2014) “Musethica: Un proyecto educativo diferente” http://www.operaworld.es/musethica/

== External links == * {{official website|http://www.musethica.org}} * [http://www.gotlandchamber.se/musethica.html Gotland Chamber Music Festival: “Musethica”] * [http://www.fondationcarasso.org/es/content/musethica Daniel ¬ Nina Carasso Foundation: “Musethica”]

{{Infobox film | name = Nine Months | image = Nine months.jpg | caption = Theatrical release poster | director = [[Chris Columbus (filmmaker)|Chris Columbus]] | producer = [[Michael Barnathan]]
Anne François
Mark Radcliffe
Chris Columbus | based on = {{based on|''[[Neuf mois]]''
1994 French film|[[Patrick Braoudé]]}} | screenplay = [[Patrick Braoudé]]
Chris Columbus | story = Patrick Braoudé
[[Daniel Russo]] | starring = {{plainlist| * [[Hugh Grant]] * [[Julianne Moore]] * [[Tom Arnold (actor)|Tom Arnold]] * [[Joan Cusack]] * [[Jeff Goldblum]] * [[Robin Williams]]}} | music = [[Hans Zimmer]] | cinematography = [[Donald McAlpine]] | editing = [[Raja Gosnell]]
[[Stephen E. Rivkin]] | studio = [[1492 Pictures]] | distributor = [[20th Century Fox]] | released = {{Film date|1995|7|14}} | runtime = 103 minutes | country = United States | language = English | budget = | gross = $138.5 million{{cite web| title = Nine Months | work = [[Box Office Mojo]] | url = http://www.boxofficemojo.com/movies/?id=ninemonths.htm | accessdate = 2010-09-29}} }} '''''Nine Months''''' is a 1995 [[romantic comedy]] film directed by [[Chris Columbus (filmmaker)|Chris Columbus]]. It stars [[Hugh Grant]], [[Julianne Moore]], [[Tom Arnold (actor)|Tom Arnold]], [[Joan Cusack]], [[Jeff Goldblum]], and [[Robin Williams]]. The movie is a US [[remake]] of the French movie ''[[Neuf mois]]'' and served as Grant's first US starring role. It was filmed on location in the [[San Francisco Bay Area]]. The original music score was composed by [[Hans Zimmer]]. ==Plot== {{more plot|date=August 2013}} Child psychologist Samuel Faulkner has an ideal romance with ballet teacher Rebecca Taylor. Rebecca is thinking about marriage and children. Samuel is against the idea of marriage as he is happy with how things are between them. This all changes when Rebecca declares she is pregnant, and when questioned by Samuel about her birth control she replies birth control is only 97% effective. Samuel's fears mount due to his encounters with overbearing couple Marty and Gail Dwyer and their unruly daughters, as well as the confusing advice he gets from Sean, his perpetually single artist friend and Gail's brother. Samuel is confused and unsure about what to do. Feeling neglected, Rebecca leaves him and moves in with Marty and Gail. Samuel tries to contact her but she does not respond. When a girl makes a move on Samuel, he declines, saying he's not ready to move on yet. When he sees an ultrasound of his soon-to-be-born son, he decides that it is time to take responsibility before it is too late. He sells his [[Porsche 911]], buys a family van, and gets back together with Rebecca. They then marry and have their baby together.http://whataboutpregnancy.blogspot.com/ ==Cast== {{div col}} * [[Hugh Grant]] as Samuel Faulkner * [[Julianne Moore]] as Rebecca Taylor-Faulkner * [[Tom Arnold (actor)|Tom Arnold]] as Marty Dwyer * [[Joan Cusack]] as Gail Dwyer * [[Jeff Goldblum]] as Sean Fletcher * [[Robin Williams]] as Dr. Kosevich * Mia Cottet as Lili * Joey Simmrin as Truman * [[Ashley Johnson]] as Shannon Dwyer * [[Alexa Vega]] as Molly Dwyer * Aislin Roche as Patsy Dwyer * [[Zelda Williams]] as Little Girl No. 3 in Ballet Class * [[Charles Martinet]] as Arnie * [[Kristin Davis]] as Tennis Attendant * Priscilla Alden as Older Woman {{div col end}} ==Reception== The film was poorly received by critics. [[Rotten Tomatoes]] gives the film a score of 26% based on 27 reviews, with an average rating of 4.4/10.{{cite web|title=Nine Months (1995)|url=http://www.rottentomatoes.com/m/nine_months/|website=Rotten Tomatoes|accessdate=15 February 2018}} [[Roger Ebert]] gave the film two stars, saying, "''Nine Months'' is one of those movies where the outcome is abundantly clear to everyone but the hero, who remains in the hapless position of playing dumb because, if he didn't, there wouldn't be a plot."{{cite news |title=Review: Nine Months |last = Ebert | first = Roger |authorlink=Roger Ebert |newspaper=[[Chicago Sun-Times]] |url= http://rogerebert.suntimes.com/apps/pbcs.dll/article?AID=/19950712/REVIEWS/507120301/1023 |date= 1995-07-12 | accessdate = 2010-11-11}} ===Box office=== The movie debuted at #3 at the box office behind ''[[Apollo 13 (film)|Apollo 13]]'' and ''[[Under Siege 2: Dark Territory]]'' with $12.5 million in its opening weekend.{{cite news|title= Weekend Box Office : 'Under Siege' Opens in No. 2 Spot |publisher=[[Los Angeles Times]]|date=1995-07-18|url= http://articles.latimes.com/1995-07-18/entertainment/ca-25014_1_weekend-gross|accessdate=2011-01-13|first=Elaine|last=Dutka}} ''Nine Months'' went on to gross $138.5 million worldwide. ===Hugh Grant's Opinion=== Hugh Grant has spoken disparagingly of his performance in ''Nine Months'', stating in an interview with the [[SAG-AFTRA]] Foundation that: {{quote| "I really ruined it. And it was entirely my fault. I panicked, it was such a big jump up from what I'd been paid before to what they were offering me. And the scale was inhuman to my standards, you know the scale of the production, [[20th Century Fox]], the whole thing. And I just tried much too hard, and you know I forgot to do basic acting things, like mean it. So I pulled faces and overacted, it was a shocker."{{cite article| url=https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=y3lUJt4KmJw&t=2885s| title=Conversations with Hugh Grant| author=SAG-AFTRA Foundation| publisher=YouTube.com| date=2016-08-16| access-date=2018-06-27}}}} On another occasion, he referred to director Chris Columbus as a "genius" and his "brilliant" co-stars, but further commented: {{quote|"You know, having been paid ₤20,000 or whatever it was, to do ''[[Four Weddings and a Funeral]]'', if you're suddenly paid millions, you think well I better ramp up my performance by 200 times. But all that means is that you overact grotesquely, which is what I did. So I'm always very apologetic to those people."{{cite video| url=https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=q7Z0MNq4T9Q&t=1190s| title=Hugh Grant in Conversation BAFTA New York| author=BAFTA New York| publisher=YouTube.com| date=2016-09-06| access-date=2018-06-27}}}} ==Soundtrack== * "The Time of Your Life" ** Written by [[Steve Van Zandt]] ** Performed by [[Little Steven]] * "[[These Are the Days (Van Morrison song)|These Are the Days]]" ** Written and Performed by [[Van Morrison]] * "[[Let's Get It On]]" ** Written by [[Marvin Gaye]] and [[Ed Townsend]] ** Performed by Marvin Gaye * "[[Baby, I Love You]]" ** Written by [[Phil Spector]], [[Ellie Greenwich]] and [[Jeff Barry]] ** Performed by [[The Ronettes]] * "[[Turn Back the Hands of Time]]" ** Written by Bonnie F. Thompson and Jack Daniels ** Performed by [[Tyrone Davis]] * "[[19th Nervous Breakdown]]" ** Written by [[Mick Jagger]] and [[Keith Richards]] ** Performed by [[The Rolling Stones]] ==References== {{Reflist}} ==External links== * {{IMDb title|0113986|Nine Months}} * {{Allmovie title|134917|Nine Months}} * {{tcmdb title|id=85041}} * {{AFI film|id=60042|title=Nine Months}} * {{mojo title|ninemonths|Nine Months}} * {{rotten-tomatoes|nine_months|Nine Months}} {{Chris Columbus}} [[Category:1995 films]] [[Category:American films]] [[Category:English-language films]] [[Category:20th Century Fox films]] [[Category:1990s romantic comedy films]] [[Category:American romantic comedy films]] [[Category:American remakes of French films]] [[Category:Films directed by Chris Columbus]] [[Category:Films set in the San Francisco Bay Area]] [[Category:Films shot in San Francisco]] [[Category:Pregnancy films]] [[Category:Films scored by Hans Zimmer]] [[Category:Films produced by Chris Columbus]] [[Category:Screenplays by Chris Columbus]] [[Category:Films produced by Michael Barnathan]] [[Category:1492 Pictures films]]

revision.text:
{{Expand Japanese|ノーコン・キッド 〜ぼくらのゲーム史〜|date=January 2015}} {{Infobox television | show_name = No Continue Kid:
Bokura no Game Shi | image = | genre = | creator = [[Dai Satō]] | writer = Dai Satō, Hidenori Ishiyama, Makoto Ueda, Hayashi Mori, Shirō Maeda, Masayoshi Tominaga, Tetsuya Mariko | composer = [[Yoshitoku Sunahara]] | country = Japan | language = Japanese | num_seasons = | distributor = | num_episodes = 12 | list_episodes = | executive_producer = | co_exec = | producer = Kimitaka Goka, Sayaka Iezumi, Shunsuke Suzuki, Toshikazu Nishigaya, Masayuki Akieda | asst_producer = | co-producer = | editor = | location = Set in [[Toshima-ku, Tokyo]] | camera = | runtime = 31 minutes | company = [[TV Tokyo]] | network = [[TX Network]] | picture_format = | first_aired = {{Start date|2013|10|04}} | last_aired = {{End date|2013|12|20}} | website = http://www.tv-tokyo.co.jp/noconkid/index.html | production_website = }} {{Nihongo|'''''No Continue Kid: Bokura no Game Shi'''''|ノーコン・キッド 〜ぼくらのゲーム史〜|Nō Kon · Kiddo ~ Bokura no Gēmu Shi ~|lit. "No Continue Kid: Ours Game History"}} is a [[Japanese television drama]] ran on [[TV Tokyo]] from 4 October 2013 to December 20. The series bases on Japanese [[video game industry]] since 1983 to 2013,{{cite web|title=ハマケン、テレ東深夜ドラマでゲームおたくの15歳を演じる|url=http://natalie.mu/music/news/98490|website=natalie.mu|publisher=Natasha,Inc.|accessdate=2 January 2015|date=2 September 2013}} featured three high school students' growing up.{{cite web|script-title=ja:注目ドラマ紹介 ： 「ノーコン・キッド」　ゲーム史描く異色のプレーヤーズストーリー写真特集付き記事|url=http://mantan-web.jp/2013/10/03/20131003dog00m200024000c.html|website=mantan-web.jp|publisher=Mainichi Shimbun Digital Co.Ltd|accessdate=2 January 2015|language=Japanese|date=3 October 2013}} Several of famous games were appeared in the show, such as ''[[Xevious]]'', ''[[Pac-Man]]'' and ''[[Dragon Quest II]]''.{{cite web|title=『ノーコン・キッド～ぼくらのゲーム史～』では『ゼビウス』や『ドラゴンクエストII 悪霊の神々』など、数々のジャンルの名作が登場|url=http://www.famitsu.com/news/201309/11039798.html|website=famitsu.com|publisher=Kadokawa Corporation|accessdate=2 January 2015|language=Japanese|date=11 September 2013}} == Cast == * Reiji Watanabe (渡辺 礼治) - [[Kei Tanaka]] * Fumiyoshi Takano (高野 文美) - [[:ja:波瑠|Haru]] * Akinobu Kido (木戸 明信) - [[:ja:浜野謙太|Hamano Kenta]] * Masashi Watanabe (渡辺 雅史) - [[:ja:佐藤二朗|Jirō Satō]]{{cite web|script-title=ja:『ノーコン・キッド～ぼくらのゲーム史～』キャスト発表第二弾、波瑠、浜野謙太、佐藤二朗の出演が決定|url=http://www.famitsu.com/news/201309/02039273.html|website=famitsu.com|publisher=Kadokawa Corporation|accessdate=2 January 2015|language=Japanese|date=2 September 2013}} == References == {{Reflist}} == External links == * {{Official website|http://www.tv-tokyo.co.jp/noconkid/index.html}} {{ja icon}} [[Category:2013 Japanese television series debuts]] [[Category:TV Tokyo shows]] [[Category:Works about video games]]

{{Use dmy dates|date=March 2016}} {{Infobox film | name = No Home Movie | image = No Home Movie.jpg | caption = Film poster | director = [[Chantal Akerman]] | producer = Chantal Akerman
Patrick Quinet
Serge Zeitoun | writer = Chantal Akerman | starring = Chantal Akerman
Natalia Akerman | music = | cinematography = Chantal Akerman | editing = Claire Atherton | studio = Liaison Cinématographique
Paradise Films | distributor = Zeugma Films {{small|(France)}} | released = {{Film date|df=y|2015|8|10|[[Locarno Film Festival|Locarno]]|2016|2|24|France}} | runtime = 115 minutes | country = France
Belgium | language = French
Spanish
English | budget = }} '''''No Home Movie''''' is a French-Belgian 2015 [[documentary film]] directed by [[Chantal Akerman]], focusing on conversations between the film-maker and her mother just months before her mother's death. The film premiered at the [[Locarno Film Festival]] on 10 August 2015. It is Akerman's last film.{{Citation | last =Debruge | first =Peter | title ="Film Review: No Home Movie" | publisher = ''Variety'' | date =10 August 2015 | url =https://variety.com/2015/film/reviews/no-home-movie-film-review-1201566469/ | accessdate = 24 November 2015}} ==Plot== The documentary consists of "conversations—whether in person in a neat kitchen, or over Skype from abroad—" between Akerman and her mother Natalia, who was a survivor of [[Auschwitz]].{{Citation | last =Rapold | first =Nicolas | title ="Chantal Akerman Takes Emotional Path in Film About 'Maman'" | publisher =''The New York Times'' | date =5 August 2015 | url =https://www.nytimes.com/2015/08/06/arts/international/chantal-akerman-takes-emotional-path-in-film-about-maman.html | accessdate = 24 November 2015}} Halfway through the film, Akerman cuts to a succession of traveling shots of a desert, which "cleave(s) the movie in two."{{Citation | last =Dargis | first =Manohla | title =Review: ‘No Home Movie,’ of Love and Melancholy | publisher = ''The New York Times'' | date =31 March 2016 | url =https://www.nytimes.com/2016/04/01/movies/review-no-home-movie-of-love-and-melancholy.html | access-date = 4 April 2016}} ==Production== Filming ran several months. Her mother died shortly after filming ended, at the age of 86, in April 2014. Akerman whittled down around forty hours' worth of footage to 115 minutes; she used small handheld cameras and her [[BlackBerry]] to film. "I think if I knew I was going to do this, I wouldn’t have dared to do it," Akerman in an interview with ''[[The New York Times]]''. Akerman died on 5 October 2015 in Paris. ''[[Le Monde]]'' reported that she committed [[suicide]].{{cite news|url=http://www.lemonde.fr/cinema/article/2015/10/06/la-cineaste-chantal-akerman-est-morte_4783566_3476.html|author=Isabelle Regnier|title=La cinéaste Chantal Akerman est morte|publisher=''Le Monde''|date=6 October 2015|accessdate=6 October 2015}} ==Release== The film premiered in the United States at the [[New York Film Festival]] on 7 October 2015, where it was described as "an extremely intimate film but also one of great formal precision and beauty, one of the rare works of art that is both personal and universal, and as much a masterpiece as her 1975 career-defining ''[[Jeanne Dielman|Jeanne Dielman, 23, quai du Commerce, 1080 Bruxelles]]''."{{Citation | title =Main Slate: ''No Home Movie'' | publisher =The Film Society of Lincoln Center | year =2015 | url =http://www.filmlinc.org/nyff2015/films/no-home-movie/ | accessdate = 24 November 2015}} One scene, in particular, where the two "sit at the kitchen table, eating potatoes that Ms. Akerman has prepared, telling her mother that even she, the peripatetic artist, has mastered a few domestic skills" highlights, as one ''New York Times'' reviewer suggests, "the moment as a reference to a memorable potato-peeling scene" from ''Jeanne''.{{Citation | last =Donadio | first =Rachel | title =The Director’s Director: Chantal Akerman | publisher =''The New York Times'' | date =25 March 2016 | url =https://www.nytimes.com/2016/03/27/movies/the-directors-director-chantal-akerman.html | access-date = 26 March 2016}} ==References== {{reflist}} ==External links== * {{IMDB title|tt4881016}} * [https://www.nytimes.com/2016/04/01/movies/review-no-home-movie-of-love-and-melancholy.html Review] from ''[[The New York Times]]'' * [http://tiff.net/festivals/festival15/wavelengths/no-home-movie Profile and trailer at the Toronto International Film Festival] {{Chantal Akerman}} [[Category:2015 films]] [[Category:Belgian films]] [[Category:Documentary films about women]] [[Category:Documentary films about the Holocaust]] [[Category:Films directed by Chantal Akerman]] [[Category:French films]] [[Category:French-language films]] [[Category:English-language films]] [[Category:Films shot in Brussels]] [[Category:Films shot in Israel]]

revision.text:
{{Infobox book | name = On Social Freedom | title_orig = | translator = | image = On Social Freedom in Oxford and Cambridge Review 1907.jpg | caption = Title page of Mill's ''On Social Freedom'' featured for the first time in [[The Oxford and Cambridge Review]], June 1907. | author = Falsely attributed to [[John Stuart Mill]]; most likely written by Ebenezer R. Edger | illustrator = | cover_artist = | country = [[England]] | language = [[English language|English]] | series = | subject = Individual and Societal Freedom | genre = [[Philosophy]] | publisher = Archibald Constable & Co. Ltd. | release_date = 1907 | media_type = Print | pages = 57-83 | preceded_by = | followed_by = }} '''On Social Freedom: or the Necessary Limits of Individual Freedom Arising Out of the Conditions of Our Social Life''' is an essay regarding individual and societal freedom initially thought to have been written by the British philosopher [[John Stuart Mill]],Dawson, Oswald. "On Social Freedom." In Oxford and Cambridge Review (London: Archibald Constable & Co. Ltd., 1907) pp. 57-83. but later found to have been falsely attributed to him.Rees, J.C. ''Mill and His Early Critics'' (Leicester: University College, 1956), pp. 38-54 Discovered in 1907 among the possessions left in the home at which Mill died in [[Avignon, France]], it was published in June 1907 as a special article in [[The Oxford and Cambridge Review]].Oxford and Cambridge Review on Google Books, "John Stuart Mill: On Social Freedom: or the Necessary Limits of Individual Freedom Arising Out of the Conditions of Our Social Life", June 1907 The work was republished by Columbia University Press in 1941, but failed to attract much attention. In 1955, the Liberal Arts Press intended to republish it in a volume also containing ''[[On Liberty]]'', but decided against doing so in view of the doubts surrounding its authorship raised by the Mill scholar J.C. Rees. He then set out the full case against attributing the work to Mill in his 1956 work ''Mill and His Early Critics''. Rees's explanation for how the manuscript ended up among Mill's possessions is summarised by J.P. Scanlan:Scanlan, J.P. "J.S. Mill and the Definition of Freedom", Ethics, Vol. 68, No. 3 (University of Chicago Press, April 1958), p. 200
In September, 1862, Mill wrote a letter from Avignon to a certain E.R. Edger, acknowledging receipt of a manuscript entitled "Social Freedom." Apparently Edger hoped to elicit from Mill an appraisal of his capacity for philosophical inquiry, and had sent the manuscript as a sample of his work. Mill replies politely and with his usual care that he finds many signs of competence in the work - mostly, however, in the form of "promise rather than performance" - and he exhorts Edger to continue thinking and writing, though not "to the neglect of other modes of gaining a subsistence." Concerining Edger's views Mill says only that, if he were to comment in detail, he "should have much to say against several of your positions, and especially against your definition of liberty."The Letters of John Stuart Mill, ed. Hugh S.R. Elliot (London: Longmans, Green & Co., 1910), Volume 1, pp. 259-61
The letter is included in Mill's ''Collected Works''The Collected Works of John Stuart Mill, Vol. XV: The Later Letters 1849-1873 Part II, (University of Toronto Press 1963), p. 792 where Edger is identified as "probably Ebenezer R. Edger, associate of [[George Holyoake|G.J. Holyoake]] in the promoting of the [[history of the cooperative movement|co-operative movement]], writer for ''The Secular World'' and author of tracts on co-operation." Holyoake briefly mentions Edger in ''The History of Co-operation'':Holyoake, George Jacob, The History of Co-operation (T. Fisher Unwin, 1906 [Vol. 1: 1875, Vol. 2: 1879])
"Ten years later my colleague, Mr E. R. Edger, visited Mr. Crisell, the manager of the farm whom the Rev. Mr. Robinson had found to be "manly, open, and ingenious appearance," beyond what he expected of one belonging to the "depressed" class. Mr. Edger sent me this report:-
"I paid a visit to Assington, and had a conversation with the manager, Mr. Crisell (pronounced with i long, 'Cry-sell'). I can feel no enthusiasm at all about the Assington Farm. There seems no 'co-operation' in the right sense of the term, but only ''bounty'' of the squire towards poor neighbours. (1) It is limited to inhabitants of the parish. (2) Each member can hold only one share. (3) Members have no voice in the management. (4) Wages to workmen same as usual. (5) No special inducement offered to the workmen to become shareholders. The manager remarked that they did not care particularly to employ the members; this seems to me very significant. It has been in existence forty-one years, so it will take a long time to renovate society that way. Remember, I only give my impressions."
An E.R. Edger is also listed in The British Medical Journal on the 24th of April 1869 as having passed a primary examination in anatomy and physiology at the Royal College of Surgeons of England.The British Medical Journal, April 24, 1869, p. 389 == References == {{Reflist}} == External links == * [https://books.google.com/books?id=WuAjAQAAIAAJ&pg=PA57&source=gbs_toc_r&cad=4#v=onepage&q&f=false] - Oxford and Cambridge Review, June 1907 * [http://liberologi.wordpress.com/2011/10/01/on-social-freedom-by-john-stuart-mill/] - Social liberty, published 1941. Complete html version. * [http://europepmc.org/backend/ptpmcrender.fcgi?accid=PMC2259812&blobtype=pdf] - The British Medical Journal, April 24, 1869 [[Category:Articles created via the Article Wizard]] [[Category:John Stuart Mill]] [[Category:Social philosophy literature]] [[Category:Unfinished creative works]] [[Category:Modern philosophical literature]] [[Category:Constable & Co. books]] [[Category:1907 essays]]

The following [[Outline (list)|outline]] is provided as an overview of and topical guide to aesthetics:
'''[[Aesthetics]]''' – branch of [[philosophy]] and [[axiology]] concerned with the nature of [[beauty]]. {{TOC limit|limit=2}}
== What ''type'' of thing is an aesthetic? ==
Aesthetics can be described as all of the following: * [[Philosophy#Branches of philosophy|Branch of philosophy]] – ** Branch of [[axiology]] –
== Related academic areas == * [[Aesthetics of music]] * [[Applied aesthetics]] * [[Architecture]] * [[Art]] * [[Arts criticism]] * [[Gastronomy]] * [[History of aesthetics (pre-20th-century)]] * [[History of painting]] * [[Painting]] * [[Philosophy of film]] * [[Philosophy of music]] * [[Poetry]] * [[Sculpture]] * [[Theory of painting]]
== History of aesthetics ==

== Theories of aesthetics and art movements ==

== Philosophers of art and aestheticians ==
* [[Theodor W. Adorno]] * [[Alexander Gottlieb Baumgarten]] * [[Arthur Schopenhauer]] * [[David Hume]] * [[Friedrich Nietzsche]] * [[Georg Wilhelm Friedrich Hegel|G. W. F. Hegel]] * [[Immanuel Kant]] * [[Paul Klee]] * [[Jean-François Lyotard]] * [[Joseph Margolis]] * [[Martin Heidegger]] * [[Nelson Goodman]] * [[Richard Wollheim]] * [[Thierry de Duve]] * [[George Santayana]] * [[Hubert Dreyfus]] * [[John Dewey]] * [[Friedrich Schiller]] * [[György Lukács]] * [[Jacques Maritain]] * [[Bernard Bosanquet (philosopher)|Bernard Bosanquet]] * [[Clive Bell]] * [[I. A. Richards]] * [[José Ortega y Gasset]] * [[R. G. Collingwood]] * [[David Prall]] * [[Dewitt H. Parker]] * [[Edward Bullough]] * [[Irving Singer]] * [[Roger Fry]] * [[Stephen Pepper]] * [[Susanne Langer]] * [[Theodor Lipps]] * [[Thomas Munro]] * [[Curt John Ducasse]] * [[Arthur Danto]] * '''[[List of aestheticians|more ...]]'''
